titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

lg.l: Eternal Spirit! Ruler of the Skies!
From whom all good and perfect gifts arise;
Oh! grant that while this feeble hand pourtrays
The fleeting image of my earthly days,
Still the firm purpose of this heart may be
Good to Mankind, and Gratitude to thee!
And while the page, a true resemblance bears
Of all my changes, through a life of cares,
Let not one worthless deed here claim a place,
To stain the future, or the past disgrace.
Nor yet one thought the faithful record swell
But such as Virtue may delight to tell.

div.p: At noon this day, I left my house, at the Corner of Boylston and Nassau Streets in Boston, accompanied by my wife, my youngest child, Charles-Francis, My wife’s Sister, Catherine Johnson, My nephew and private Secretary William Steuben Smith, Martha Godfrey, who attends my wife as her chambermaid, and a black man-servant named Nelson, to embark on a voyage to Russia, charged with a Commission as Minister Plenipotentiary from the United States of America to that Court. We went in a Carriage, over Charles river Bridge, to Mr: William Gray’s wharf at Charlestown; we there went on board his Ship Horace, Captain Bickford, fitted out on a voyage to St: Petersburg direct— We found already on board the ship, Mr Alexander H. Everett, and Mr: Francis S. Gray, who are going with me, as Secretaries attached to the Legation, but at their own expence. Mr: and Mrs: Gray were also at the vessel, with two of their other sons— There were also a number of Gentlemen there who took leave of us at the wharf— We left it precisely as the Boston and Charlestown Bells were ringing One O’Clock.— Doctor Welsh and my brother went with us, down the harbour, and some short distance without the light-house— We received on our passage Salutes at the Navy-Yard in Charlestown, at Fort-Independence on Castle-Island, the Garrison of which was paraded as we pass’d; from the Revenue Cutter, Massachusetts, Captain Williams, and from the Chesapeake Frigate, Captain Hull, which lay anchored about two miles without the light; and from which Captain Hull, sent an Officer on board with his compliments, and wishing us a pleasant passage. We returned the Salutes, and the compliments as well as we could— We had a fair wind, and a tolerably fresh breeze— About 4 in the afternoon my brother and Dr: Welsh took leave of us, and went on board the revenue Cutter, to return to Boston; we then stood out with a light breeze, and fair weather, which continued all the Evening, and had almost lost sight of the land, before the darkness of Night intercepted the shores from our view.

At this Commencement of an Enterprize, perhaps the most important of any that I have ever in the course of my life, been engaged in, it becomes me to close the day by imploring the blessing of Providence upon it— That its result may prove beneficial to my Country, prosperous to my family and myself; and advantageous to all who are concerned in the voyage.

6. Sunday.— On rising this morning we found ourselves out of sight of land— Weather cool and foggy— Winds light, and rather scant— About South; with some East— All the Ladies—Charles—and Mr: Everett who has never before been to sea, are sick. Mr: Gray, who likewise is a new Sailor, has not yet been so— Mr: Smith and myself scarcely perceive that we are at sea.

This is the fourth time that in the course of my life, I have embarked from Boston for Europe— The first was 11. Feby: 1778. in the Boston Frigate, Captain Tucker— The second 14. November 1779. in the Sensible, French Frigate, Captain Chavagnes. The third 17. September 1794. In the Alfred, merchant-ship, Captain Macey— On the first and second of these voyages, I accompanied my father, who was going abroad upon public missions— On the third, I went in a similar character myself, and was accompanied by my brother— The separation from my family and friends has always been painful; but never to the degree, which I feel it now— The age of my Parents, weakens both in them and me the hopes of our meeting again; and I now leave two of my own infant children behind— My father and Mother are also deeply affected by my departure, and I received yesterday from my Mother a letter which would have melted the heart of a Stone.— The ties which bind me to my Country have multiplied with the increase of my years, and the difficulties and dangers of every kind, which present themselves in anticipation upon this occasion, exceed those of any former time— Excepting however the dangers of War to which on my two first voyages I was exposed; and which do not threaten us now— My Motives for accepting this Commission are various— That of serving my Country, in the Station which its regular organs have chosen to assign me, stands foremost of them all; and though it neither suits my own inclination, nor my own private judgment, I deem it a duty to sacrifice them both to the public sense, express’d by the Constitutional authority.

I had yesterday previous to my embarking, completed my preparatory arrangements, as far as they could be completed. I leave my brother my Agent, for the transaction of all my business in America— I had settled with Mr: Gray, and paid him for our passage; and after we came on board, I gave my brother a check for the balance due me at the U.S. Bank—Boston. I called in the forenoon at Mr: William Smith’s and Dr: Welsh’s— And took leave of their families— Of the rest of my friends I took no particular leave— Heaven bless them all!— My brother had come into Boston the Evening before last—to be with us at the time of our departure— He had a son born in the morning; before he came from Quincy.

The weather and the winds are among the most interesting objects to navigators upon the Ocean— We had a thick fog, the greatest part of this day. The wind fair, but scanty and not strong— We saw at a distance two schooners, but spoke neither of them— Our course has been about East & by South— Latitude by Observation this day 42:34. The variation at Boston is about 8 degrees— About 4 this afternoon we came to the Northern extremity of St: George’s Bank, 42 leagues from Boston.— I employed part of the morning in writing, and arranging my papers— And it being Sunday, I read the second and third Sermons of Massillon’s Carême— The one, on the motives for Conversion, and the other on the truth of Religion— There is too much sameness in the method of these Sermons— In the former there is a very eloquent passage of invective upon the vices of the time; with a fine example of repetition from Psalm 101.20. [“]Prospexit de excelso sancto suo.”— And there are frequent melancholy allusions to the misfortunes of France at that period—the close of the reign of Louis 14.— The political views of these Sermons should be compared with those of Saurin’s, and Tillotson’s, on the same occasions, to see how improper almost all Politicks are for the pulpit— There is also here a little controversy against the Protestants. He insists on the antiquity of the Catholic Faith, as a proof of its Truth— He urges also the importance of the church’s precepts of abstinence, and complains that they are not sufficiently respected even by the true believers— His arguments on this head are chiefly from authority, of jewish examples— The strongest is the parallel, between the sin of Adam, in eating an apple against the injunction of abstinence, and that of Cain in killing his brother, in violation of the injunction against homicide.

7. The fog comes and goes from hour to hour— Last Night it was almost gone— This morning again it was very thick. And the weather has become very cool. This morning about nine O’Clock we spoke a fishing Schooner from the Grand Bank; belonging and bound to Plymouth.— The fog was so thick that we did not see her untill within speaking distance, and she
pass’d so quickly by us, that we had not time to learn her name— I employed most of the forenoon in writing; and began a letter to my brother, to be sent whenever an opportunity shall present itself— The afternoon I pass’d in reading Chantreau’s Travels in Russia— I find that after all the pains I had taken to have l’Evesque’s history of Russia with me, it has been packed up, if at-all, in one of the boxes which I cannot open on the passage.— Before I sailed I felt uncertain what kind of books I should most incline to— I now find that it is those relating to Russia; and I have nothing but Chantreau. My thermometer reminds me of Williams’s thermometrical Navigation, which I regret not having taken with me. But I took the temperature of the Water and of the Atmosphere at Noon, and at Sunset.— Noon Water 56. Air 66. with a thick fog. Sunset Water 62. Air 65.— The Captain could get no observation this day.

8. Continuance of thick fogs through the whole day, with light and fair winds— No observation— Saw one vessel, a Schooner bound inward this forenoon.— Water at Noon 63. Air 67— Evening—Water 63. Air 64.— Employed the morning in writing— Afternoon reading Langhorne’s Life of Plutarch— And part of the life of Theseus— In the Evening a little of Chantreau— I was not very well. About Noon, the Captain supposed us nearly abreast of Halifax—in Latitude 63— Our Course has been constantly East & by South, which allowing for the variation, makes a course a little North of East— Their usual wish is to meet the Grand Bank in Latitude 44.

9. Fogs in the former part of the Night— Fresh breeze the remainder— About day break we pass’d a schooner, bound nearly the same course with us— The Captain got an observation— Latitude 43:29.— At dinner we were suddenly surprized with a severe Squall, and during the remainder of the day, the weather was squally— The water by the thermometer was at 62 this morning and 63 at Noon— Our Captain supposes we were this morning abreast of Sable Island— Longitude 61.— The Ladies are still sick most of the time, and the child is yet excessively fractious.

10. A night of frequent squalls and alternate calms; the vessel labouring very heavily— I was up three or four times in the Night, and got no sleep— Heavy Rains all the morning, with a sultry atmosphere— I think we must be in the gulf-stream— The water this morning was at 67. the air at 70— After several hours of copious rain the sky cleared off, but the remainder of the day was a flat calm, with a swell which made the vessel labour— Mrs: Adams was very sick, and the child troublesome— Catherine and Martha, were also both sick.— I read some chapters in the Bible, Plutarch’s life of Romulus, and some of Mrs: Grant’s letters from the Mountains— (Scotch Mountains.) A ship was seen this day at a distance— Latitude by Observation 43:49. Longitude 56:30.

11. Another very bad Night; in which I got no sleep, and was up half the night— The child and my wife both being sick— When I experience such excessive irritation upon the nervous system, reason should teach me to make allowances for the same upon others; especially upon nerves naturally more irritable— The Night was almost entirely calm— I employed much of it in reading Mrs: Grant’s letters, which I find more interesting than Plutarch— I return to them of choice; but Plutarch is a task, and a heavy one— I never could read him through— I find it especially hard to read him after a sleepless Night— After two, harder still— The calm continued through the day; with fine weather— A light breeze in the Evening, with the wind a-head— This day was the new Moon— Jupiter rose about nine this Evening.— We saw nothing the whole of this day— Latitude by observation 43:39.— Temperature of the Water in the Morning 67. at Noon 68. That of the atmosphere the same— Towards Evening the water being smoother I became more tranquil.

12. Having slept much of the last Night, I was better able to read and write this day; but wrote very little— Read Plutarch, and Mrs: Grant, and Chantreau, besides the usual portion of the bible— But the days for Patience are come— With the new Moon, the course of the winds has changed from West to East, and after a calm morning, we have had all this day a stiff breeze, blowing directly a-head. Part of the time threatening a gale of Wind— Saw nothing through the course of the day—not even a fish— Nothing but the birds which the sailors call mother Cary’s chickens, which I have always found constant attendants on the Atlantic Ocean— But I never was so long at sea before without seeing fish—particularly porpoises.— Latitude by the dead reckoning at noon 43:52.— Water in the morning 69. Noon 70. Our course during the day was about North, and just as Night came on we went on the other tack about South— Very little of East gained upon either.— I read in Plutarch the lives of Lycurgus, and of Numa, with the parallel between them— But with a Cabin about 20 feet Square, between seven persons and a child, which is the eating room, and bed-chamber of all the company, I find the power of self-abstraction, fails.

13. Head winds and fogs continually rising and dispersing through the day— Saw nothing— I read over again Plutarch’s life of Lycurgus, and made some minutes from it— In the afternoon also, I read two Sermons of Massillon— On the forgiveness of injuries, and on the word of God— The first of these is the best of this author’s Sermons that I have yet read— The subject is indeed most interesting and copious— And the manner in which he treats it is adapted peculiarly to his auditory—to men of the world and courtiers— The divisions of the subject, are still too technical— The injustice of our enmities, and the insincerity of our reconciliations are the two parts— The first, subdivided into three—Taste—Interest—Vanity, which are the causes of our taking offence— The second also into three— The motives, process, and consequences of pretended reconciliation— There is some censure in this discourse upon the practice of dueling— There is argument, satire, indignation, tenderness, a keen search of every good corner in the heart, and every sound cellar of the brain. In the second Sermon, on preaching there is more ingenuity but less pathos— The division is founded on the dispositions with which believers ought to attend on preaching, and on those with which they should hear it— In this Sermon there is a passage very much to my purpose, in the Lecture which endeavours to trace the source of difference, between Catholic and Protestant preaching. It is page 170—and names docility as one of the dispositions with which preaching is to be heard— There is an anecdote told of Louis 14. that he said to Massillon after hearing one of his Sermons—Father, I have heard and admired many other preachers, but you always make me dissatisfied with myself— If Louis said so, he had taken the idea from Massillon in this Sermon— He says that many hearers come to seek vain ornaments which amuse the patient without healing him, which make the preacher pleasing to the sinner, but not the sinner displeasing to himself.— I observe in this Sermon many instances of a very peculiar manner of applying passages of Scripture figuratively— No observation of the Sun this day— Lat. 43:44— Water at 70. morning and Noon— Air about the same.

14. The day was fine— The water smooth— The winds light, but so much ahead, that we were unable at any part of the day to steer within three points of our course— Latitude by Observation 43:26. Long: 54:30— Water, Morning 67. Air 68. Noon Water 67. Air 69. I made minutes on the two Sermons of Massillon, which I read yesterday; and on Plutarch’s life of Lycurgus— Read also his life of Solon. I find amusement in these occupations, and our weather is so mild and Sea so smooth that I can employ more time in reading and writing than I ever could at sea before— Yet it seems to me that I do not employ my time to the best advantage— My thermometer is an Amusement— A celestial globe would also be an agreeable companion. And La Cepede’s Natural History of Fishes— Pinkerton’s Geography— And Mavor’s little collection of Voyages and Travels— We have seen nothing since the ship last Thursday, which the Captain says took our winds from us; but this afternoon we were entertained with a scull of porpoises, first seen by W. S. Smith; which played for an hour or two round the bow of the ship, and which some of the men with the usual ill-success attempted to catch with grains and harpoons— The water continues to bream or scintillate; which the Captain considers as a sign of Easterly winds.

15. A Fair day, with light breezes— But the wind still keeps us two points North of our course— Latitude by Observation 44:13. Longitude 53:40. our Captain would have preferr’d coming upon soundings in Latitude 43:30. that being the vicinity where most of the fishing vessels are accustomed to lie at Anchor.— Water this Morning 67— Air 69— At Noon the same— At Sunset 66— & 67— The Captain expected to get soundings to-morrow morning— The Caboose was this afternoon on fire.

16. It was near Midnight when I went to bed; and within an hour afterwards, I was roused, by hearing the Captain speak to a fishing vessel lying at anchor in 38 fathoms Water on the Grand Bank of Newfoundland— We rose immediately and I closed two of my letters for my brother and my mother, which I sealed to have them all ready should the opportunity to put them on board another vessel occur. There was a very thick fog, and soon after we pass’d by the fisherman, it fell to a dead calm— From 2 in the morning untill about 9. we were laying to, and fishing for Cod, upwards of sixty of which we caught— I lost the bite of a halibut; and the hook itself, part of which he carried away— About 10 this morning a light westerly breeze arose; and we got again almost before the wind— A thick fog arose, and no observation of the Sun could be obtained.— Latitude, by the dead reckoning 44:41. Longitude 51:30— Water while we were fishing in the morning 66. Air 68— Water at Noon 68. Air 76.— In the afternoon the fog cleared away, and we saw two fishing vessels laying at Anchor— We bore down and spoke to one of them, which was the Dove, of Plymouth— The Captain sent his first mate, Mr: Poland, on
on board her, with our letters for America— I sent one to my mother, one to my brother, and one to Mr: Casaux at Portsmouth, New-Hampshire— It will be some time before they can be received, for the vessel expects to lay here on the Banks, six weeks longer— She has been out from Plymouth fifteen days— Six of them here, and has caught already five thousand fish— She has seven men— Their usual fare is about 30,000, and a thousand is a good day’s haul— They sometimes take as many as fifteen hundred in a day— We pass’d so nearly by this vessel, that we almost ran foul of her.— In the Evening we had several light showers of rain.

17. A Fair day, with a light and favourable breeze— Morning very warm; but growing cooler the whole day— Latitude by Observation 45:23.— Longitude 50:37.— About 8 in the Evening we are supposed to have reached the eastern extremity of the Grand Bank of Newfoundland— Water in the Morning 68. Air 71. Noon Water 65. Air 69— Sunset Water 64. Air 66.— I read the lives of Themistocles and Camillus in Plutarch— Wrote little— The day was so fine that I could not avoid spending much of it upon deck— We saw nothing.— Showers of rain in the Evening.

18. Fogs, through the day and Evening; so thick that no observation could be taken— Latitude by the reckoning 46:32. Long: 48:50 Water, Morning 61. Air 64. Noon. Water 60. Air 63. Sunset. Water 59. Air 61.— Winds light and fair— Saw nothing— We are indeed now out of the usual track of any constant Navigation— I finished reading Mrs: Grant’s letters, and the first volume of Langhorne’s Plutarch— The life of Pericles is as interesting as any in the volume— I also wrote a little, upon a plan which I wish systematically to pursue— Charles is this day two years old.

19. Continuance of a thick fog and fair wind all last Night and the whole of this day— Part of the time blowing so fresh as to bring us eight and eight and a half knots an hour— Split one of our Studding-sails— And part of the crew were employed all day in making a new one. The fog made it necessary to use precautions for avoiding the possible chance of running foul of some other vessel— The expedient is blowing a horn at short intervals of five or ten minutes upon the forecastle— We saw nothing— I read the life of Fabius Maximus in Plutarch— No Observation— Lat: 48— Long: 45:37.— Water— Morning. 60. Air 63. Evening. Water 59. Air 63.

20. Wind died away early this morning, and left us a day of total calm— The sky was more clear and W. S. Smith discovered a vessel astern of us, which he shewed to the Captain, but which none of the rest of us could see— Latitude by Observation 48:35. Long: 43:50.— Water 59. and 60. Air 62. and 64.— I read two Sermons of Massillon; on the certainty of a future State, and on the Reverence to be observed in Churches— They pleased me less than those of the last week— The reasoning in support of a future state is upon the obvious topics— Its necessity, for the moral government of the Universe— And the opinion entertained by all mankind— He does not touch upon the analogies in physical nature which render futurity more probable— The Sermon upon the duty of reverend behaviour at church, is upon an article of the minor morals, but breathes a fervent Spirit of devotion— He compliments the king Louis 14. upon his exemplary piety, in attendance upon Church; but he bitterly censures the Courtiers who come to attract their Master’s notice, by an affectation of religion which they do not feel; and the worldly women, who come to display a pomp of apparel, or to make assignations of galantry— He particularly handles very roughly their nudities— This was about the time when Addison frown’d upon the naked Arms of the English women— There is a curious account of the four degrees of entrenchment round the sanctuary of the Temple under the antient Jewish Laws.— This Evening we had the return of a very light wind, with fog and mist, which seems in these Seas, at this Season to be invariable attendants on a westerly wind.

21. The fog continued through the night, but cleared away this morning, with a fresh westerly breeze which stood steady all day; and became brisker this Evening— This was the finest we have had since we sailed— Accompanied however with symptoms of approaching foul weather. Latitude By Observation 49:23— Long: 41:53.— Water this Morning 59. Air 60.— At Noon Water 67. air 70.— We saw Nothing, but a number of birds. I read Plutarch’s life of Alcibiades, and wrote a little; but with several interruptions.

22. The beautiful Evening of last Night, was succeeded by a brisk gale, in which our rigging suffered some damage. It arose immediately after the setting of the moon which was about 1. in the Morning— The wind continued fair; but so fresh that we were part of the time under a reefed fore top-sail, and had the dead-lights in our cabin down all this morning. Latitude by Observation 51:11. Long: 38:51. Water. Morning 64. Air 67.— Noon. Water 60. Air 64— Read Plutarch’s life of Coriolanus, and the parallel between him and Alcibiades.— Writing, all the afternoon— We amused the Evening with cards— Saw a large number of birds— The wind somewhat subsided in the Evening.

23. About midnight the wind came round to W.N.W. and blew a gale the whole of this day— In the 24 hours from noon to noon we ran 186 miles— We ran part of this day under reef’d top-sails— And so heavy a swell of the sea arose, that I could not write a line this day— I read in Plutarch the lives of Timoleon and Paulus AEmilius, with the parallel— The rolling of the vessel has been so great and so uneasy that I have been bereft of sleep almost entirely the two last Nights— The straining of this perpetual motion is a trial both to the mind and body— It gave me this Evening, a dull head-ache, with which I retired to bed— Latitude by Observation 52:46. Longitude 34:30.— Water: Morning 56. Air 58. Noon Water 55: air 57.

24. The wind having died away early in the night, leaving a heavy swell behind, we had another night of uncomfortable rolling— I was up again part of the Night, and lost most of the remainder without sleep— After about four hours of calm, a Wind sprung up again; nearly South; with dull weather and rain— No observation— Latitude by the reckoning 53:59. Longitude 30:48.— Water Morning 55. Air 57. Noon Water 54. Air 56.— I read the life of Pelopidas in Plutarch; but suffered so much weariness that I could neither write nor read with satisfaction— In the Evening after a variety of weather, cleared away in the sequel to a long and heavy shower of rain. Saw nothing but birds.

25. Moderate breezes and fair weather with occasional showers of rain. A heavy swell from the Northwest occasioned so much rolling of the vessel that I could neither write nor read much— A loss of sleep, almost total for the three preceding Nights also disqualified me for application or reflection— I read however the life of Marcellus in Plutarch; and the parallel between him and Pelopidas— And in the Evening I read Absalom and Achitophel— The principal difference between Dryden’s part and Tate’s, is the aptness of Dryden’s scriptural allusions— The resemblance between the two parts is much too great— And the wit is too coarse and vulgar— We had cards in the cabin this Evening— Latitude by Observation 55:36.— Long: 28:20.— Water 54. Air 56. Saw nothing but a Grampus.

26. Mild and moderate weather: with very light winds, last Night, and the whole of this day. Occasional showers of rain with alternate hours of Sun-shine— A vessel was seen this morning a-stern, steering her course about South-east— Our course from the Grand Bank, and indeed from our departure has been by the compass East by South, which in consequence of the variation, brings us nearly to a course East North-East— The variation which at Boston is about 8. degrees continually increases, and is now nearly two points and a half— Our Latitude by Observation this day was 56:31.— Longitude 26:10.— Water 53. Air 55. I shall in future mark it only once a day.— I read the lives of Aristides and of Cato the Censor in Plutarchs and something of the life of Mahomet, introductory to Savary’s french Translation of the Koran.

27. A Fine day, with a favourable but very light wind— Latitude by Observation 57:39. Longitude 23:50.— I read two Sermons of Massillon—on Relapse; and on Prayer— Relapses, are connected with the system of auricular confession— It is the repetition of sin, after absolution received. We who do not believe that a man can absolve our sins, are in no danger of relapse; but then our sins accumulate upon us through the whole course of our lives— The Sermon upon Prayer is very good— He follows his usual course of argument; which consists principally of reply to objections— The discourse is divided into two parts— 1. Answering those who say they know not how— 2. Those who find it tedious & disgusting. During the remainder of the day I employed some time in reflection; a time which to me is too often lost— For reflection is of no use in itself— Its value is found only in its fruits— The greatest curiosity this day seen was a lunar rainbow, which I do not recollect ever to have seen before— Water by the Thermometer 53. Air 55.Catherine 25.

28. Last Night, about midnight commenced a total calm which continued through the whole of this day— With intervals of wind never enough to carry us two miles an hour— Saw nothing, but a whale and some birds— Noddies— Hagdens— Sea-Pigeons, Mackerel birds and ice-birds are the names which the Captain gives to those we have seen daily on the passage— Our Latitude by Observation this day was 58:19. Longitude 22:10.— Water 53. Air 55— Cards in the cabin this Evening— I read the lives of Philopoemen and Flaminius in Langhorne’s Plutarch, and the Parallel between them, which concludes the second volume.

29. Calm continued all last Night— This day there has been a very light wind; but variable and chiefly too far East to favour us— We have never exceeded three miles an hour— Saw nothing but birds.— Latitude by Observation 58:25 Long: 20:53. Water and Air 52— I read the lives of Pyrrhus and Caius Marius in Plutarch— Something of Savary’s life of Mahomet— Cards this Evening.

30. Commencement day at Cambridge— Which we commemorated as much as we could. Our winds continue very light and variable; with frequent calms and showers, and occasional squalls— Cards again this Evening. I read in Plutarch the lives of Lysander and Sylla; but without finishing the last.— Latitude by Observation 58:50— Longitude 19:20.— Water 54. Air 52.— Saw nothing but birds.

31. Calm, and very light winds continue through this day— Weather very pleasant.— Cards in the Evening. Nothing seen— Latitude by Observation 59:23. Long: 17:15.— We are but about 200 miles distant from the most Southern part of Iceland.— I read the lives of Cimon and Lucullus in Plutarch, leaving the latter unfinished. Water and Air 53.

Day. I rise about six O’Clock—often earlier— Read ten or fifteen chapters in the bible— We breakfast about 9.— Spend half an hour afterwards upon deck— At noon sometimes take the observation by the Quadrant—read or write in the Cabin untill 2.— Dine— After dinner read or write again; occasionally visiting the deck for a walk untill 7. in the Evening— Sup— Read or play at cards untill 11. or 12. when we all retire to bed.— There is much time for study and for meditation at Sea; and when the weather is as moderate as we have generally had it hitherto upon this passage, a person capable of useful application may employ his time to as great advantage as on shore. The objects which excite attention are concentrated within the bounds of the vessel, the rest of mankind for the time seem to be inhabitants of another planet— The prosperity of the voyage consists in the paucity of incident— And the less there is to be told the more there is to be enjoyed. This life is not tedious to those who can make for themselves occupation— But its uncertainties, its perpetual changes, its anxieties, and its concentration of interest upon the fluctuations of wind and wave constitute its principal hardships.
